awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Aeolian Processes: An Overlooked Driver of State Change in Drylands?
awd_abstract_narration:
The conversion of grassland to a desert with sparse shrubs, or desertification, is occurring in areas across the world. In many cases, desertification replaces plants that livestock and wildlife prefer to eat with shrubs that are difficult for them to digest. This problem therefore threatens the livelihood of farmers and ranchers while also jeopardizing wildlife habitat. Despite the widespread occurrence of desertification, the exact causes are difficult to pinpoint. Many scientists suggest that when grazing animals choose to eat grasses over shrubs, the shrubs take over. However, desertification has often been observed in areas without livestock, so there may be multiple causes for desertification. This research intends to discover if desertification in areas with low rainfall (which tend to be sandier) is due to sand being blown by the wind (sandblasting). Windblown sand can do two things that might cause desertification: 1) erode soil and decrease its fertility and 2) damage grass plants. Because grasses require richer soils and are more fragile than shrubs, shrubs may be at an advantage where there is more wind and soil fertility is lower. Through this research, undergraduate students and a postdoctoral researcher will be trained. Outreach to K-12 teachers and students will be conducted, and will include individuals from underrepresented groups.

This research tests the following hypotheses: 1) leaf properties determine the effect of sandblasting on the plant's ability to regulate water loss and carbon uptake and to maintain an impermeable barrier to water loss during nighttime and dormant periods; 2) growth form, specifically plant height and exposure of growing points, determines vulnerability to sandblasting; 3) seedling water and nitrogen demands differ between grasses and shrubs, giving shrubs the advantage on wind-eroded soils;  4) vulnerability of new plants to sandblasting damage differs between grasses and shrubs and this vulnerability is related to soil nitrogen status; and 5) leaf and plant effects will lead to long-term changes in plant populations, culminating in a shift from grass to shrub dominance. Field experiments will be conducted on a wide range of grass and shrub growth forms. In one series of experiments, established plants will be placed in a wind tunnel that manipulates levels of sand blasting. In another, seedling establishment and growth will be quantified on sites with different soil surface characteristics associated with contrasting long-term levels of windborne transport. Results from these experiments will be integrated using models to quantitatively assess the role of these processes in driving desertification.

por.por_cntn:
Dryland ecosystems cover 40% of the Earth's land area and provide habitat for ~35% of the Earth's human population. The proliferation of shrubs accompanied by losses of grass cover and increases in soil erosion is a widely-observed form of land degradation and desertification in drylands worldwide. These undesirable changes are often assumed to be the result of livestock overgrazing reducing the ability of grasses to competitively exclude shrubs. However, there is a growing body of evidence showing this is not the whole story. This study aimed to characterize an alternative factor contributing to grassland desertification.

It is well-known that grazing-induced reductions in grass cover increases wind erosion in drylands. Intensified wind erosion would have potential, but poorly understood consequences: 1) the redistribution of soil nutrients via a ?winnowing? effect and 2) reductions plant growth caused by ?sandblasting?. We tested the hypothesis that grasses would be more negatively affected by winnowing and sandblasting than shrubs, consequently amplifying grazing- or droght-induced losses of grass cover and promoting shrub proliferation. The ?winnowing? was tested by measuring the germination and growth of various shrub and grass functional types on intact and wind-eroded surface soils. The ?sandblasting?:hypothesis was tested by placing shrub and grass plants in a wind tunnel and subjecting them to different levels winds containing different amounts of soil particles. Our experiments were conducted on plants and soils from the USDA Jornada Experimental Range in the Chihuahuan Desert.

We found that the water-holding capacity of winnowed soils was lower that that of non-winnowed soils. However, and contrary to expectations, seed germination and early growth of grass and shrub species on winnowed soils were comparable to those observed on non-winnowed soils. This may reflect the fact that our experiments were conducted under well-watered conditions. We are now testing the hypothesis that winnowing effects will be evident only when plant seedlings experience water shortages. 

Our wind-tunnel experiment revealed that sandblasting caused: 1) a decline in photosynthesis, the decline being greater in grasses than in shrubs; 2) subtantial physical damage to grass leaves; damage to shrub leaves was less severe ; 3) a marked decline of grass water use efficiency, but only a slight decline for shrubs; 4) the duration of the above physiological responses was more prolonged in grasses than in shrubs; and 5) increased leaf loss, but more so in grasses than in shrubs. 

Overall, our results suggest that the redistribution of soil nutrients by wind erosion does not differentially affect grass vs. shrub seed germination and early seedling growth when soil moisture abundant. It remains to be seen if this holds under field conditions where soil moisture content is often low. Grasses were, however, more vulnerable to sandblasting effects than shrubs. Under field conditions, sandblasting could therefore amplify grazing-induced stresses on grasses and accelerate their demise, while having little impact on shrubs. Over time, this differential response of grasses vs. shrubs to sandblasting would promote desertification in wind-erodible drylands.
